Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Wavelet Analysis of Periodic Error for Improved Displacement Metrology

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant will enable new fundamental research into displacement measuring interferometry. In the heterodyne, or two-frequency, systems to be studied here, the phase shift in laser light of one frequency reflected from a moving target relative to laser light of a second frequency reflected from a fixed target is used to determine displacement in applications requiring sub-nanometer positioning accuracy. The objective of the research is to apply wavelet analysis techniques to characterize periodic error, which is caused by mixing of the two light frequencies and leads to non-cumulative positioning errors on the order of several nanometers. Wavelets provide a new approach to signal analysis for periodic error; they have previously been used in image compression, voice recognition, and medical applications. The use of wavelets, rather than the more traditional Fourier transform approach, is required because periodic error varies with time under non-constant velocity conditions. Additionally, the error amplitude is time-varying when polarization-maintaining fibers are used to deliver the laser light to the interferometer optics. This is a common occurrence because it is generally desired to isolate the heat-generating laser source from the measurement platform.

If successful, this research will enable improved metrology capabilities and, subsequently, new technological advancements in the nano-science field. This research promises to improve the measurement technique (displacement measuring interferometry) that offers the highest performance in terms of accuracy, resolution, and range. This transducer is critical to the semiconductor manufacturing industry, for example, where it is used in a feedback control system to position the silicon wafer relative to the lithographic optics. One limitation on the achievable linewidth (and, ultimately, the chip processing speed) is the stage positioning accuracy. Other applications include transducer calibration and machines for material removal.

Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHARLOTTE, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary

Displacement interferometry is a critical metrology capability for applications requiring sub-nanometer positioning accuracy. One inherent limitation is the periodic error, or nonlinearity, caused by optical frequency mixing in commercially-available heterodyne (two frequency) systems. This error is typically quantified using a Fourier transform-based analysis of constant velocity motions. In practice, however, non-constant velocity profiles lead to non-stationary (time-dependent) signals that require alternate analysis techniques for real-time compensation. In this research, the investigators gained new insight into periodic error and its compensation by applying wavelet analysis techniques to characterize the non-stationary, amplitude-varying error caused by frequency mixing.

A new discrete time continuous wavelet transform (DTCWT)-based algorithm was used to quantify and compensate periodic error for non-constant velocity motion in heterodyne displacement measuring interferometry. It identified the periodic error by measuring the phase and amplitude information at different orders (the periodic error was modeled as a summation of pure sine signals), reconstructed the periodic error by combining the magnitudes for all orders, and compensated the periodic error by subtracting the reconstructed error from the displacement signal measured by the interferometer. The algorithm was validated by comparing the compensated results with a traditional frequency domain (FFT) approach for constant velocity motion. The algorithm demonstrated successful reduction of first and second order periodic error amplitudes. Experiments were used to validate the theoretical models.

Intellectual merit

This research provided new insight into periodic error and its compensation by applying wavelet analysis techniques to the characterization of the time-dependent error due to frequency mixing. Previously, measurement techniques focused on frequency domain approaches using, for example, the velocity scanning technique, where a high (constant) velocity motion is commanded to provide adequate separation of the intended interference signal and the periodic error components. In actual implementations, the velocity is not constant and the errors are time-dependent, so this approach cannot be applied for real-time compensation. The synergistic analysis and experimental activities completed as part of this research provided a new fundamental understanding of periodic error in displacement measuring interferometry.

Broader impacts

Improved metrology capabilities are critical for new technological advancements, particularly in the nano-science field. This research improved displacement measuring interferometry, which offers the highest performance in terms of accuracy, resolution, and range. This transducer is critical to the semiconductor manufacturing industry, for example, where it is used in a feedback control system to position the silicon wafer relative to the lithographic optics. One limitation on the achievable linewidth (and, ultimately, the chip processing speed) is the stage positioning accuracy. Other applications include transducer calibration and machines for precision material removal. Strategic education and outreach efforts were also completed to encourage the participation of students from under-represented groups.

Modified by: Tony L Schmitz
